description: A comprehensive graph of atomic-granularity concepts for understanding music theory

concepts.name: Sound
concepts.description: Vibrations traveling through air or another medium that can be heard
learning_objectives: Understand that sound is created by vibrations
Recognize that different sounds have different qualities
examples: A guitar string vibrating creates sound
Clapping hands creates a sound wave

concepts.name: Pitch
concepts.description: The perceived highness or lowness of a sound, determined by frequency
learning_objectives: Distinguish between high and low pitches
Understand that pitch is related to frequency
examples: A whistle has a high pitch
A bass drum has a low pitch
The note A440 vibrates at 440 Hz

concepts.name: Duration
concepts.description: The length of time a sound is sustained
learning_objectives: Understand that sounds can be short or long
Recognize duration as a fundamental property of musical sounds
examples: A short tap vs. a sustained tone
A quarter note vs. a whole note

concepts.name: Volume (Dynamics)
concepts.description: The loudness or softness of a sound
learning_objectives: Distinguish between loud and soft sounds
Understand volume as a musical parameter
examples: Forte (f) means loud
Piano (p) means soft

concepts.name: Timbre (Tone Color)
concepts.description: The quality or color of a sound that distinguishes different instruments or voices
learning_objectives: Identify different instruments by their sound quality
Understand that timbre is what makes a piano sound different from a violin
examples: A trumpet has a bright, brassy timbre
A flute has a pure, airy timbre

concepts.name: Musical Note
concepts.description: A symbol representing a single sound with specific pitch and duration
learning_objectives: Understand that a note combines pitch and duration
Recognize notes as the basic building blocks of music
examples: A quarter note C
A half note G

concepts.name: Note Names (Letter Names)
concepts.description: The letters A through G used to identify specific pitches
learning_objectives: Name the seven natural notes (A, B, C, D, E, F, G)
Understand that note names repeat in different octaves
examples: The white keys on a piano are named A, B, C, D, E, F, G
After G, the pattern repeats with A

concepts.name: Octave
concepts.description: The interval between one pitch and another with double or half its frequency; notes an octave apart share the same letter name
learning_objectives: Recognize that notes an octave apart sound similar but higher or lower
Understand that an octave represents a doubling or halving of frequency
examples: C4 (middle C) to C5 is one octave
A440 to A880 is one octave

concepts.name: Staff (Stave)
concepts.description: A set of five horizontal lines and four spaces used to notate music
learning_objectives: Identify the five lines and four spaces of the staff
Understand that different positions represent different pitches
examples: Notes can be placed on lines or in spaces
Higher positions on the staff indicate higher pitches

concepts.name: Clef
concepts.description: A symbol placed at the beginning of the staff to indicate which pitches are represented by the lines and spaces
learning_objectives: Understand that clefs assign specific pitches to staff positions
Recognize the purpose of different clefs for different pitch ranges
examples: Treble clef (G clef) is used for higher-pitched instruments
Bass clef (F clef) is used for lower-pitched instruments

concepts.name: Treble Clef (G Clef)
concepts.description: A clef that places G above middle C on the second line of the staff
learning_objectives: Read notes in treble clef
Identify that the treble clef curl wraps around the G line
examples: Piano right hand typically uses treble clef
Violin music is written in treble clef

concepts.name: Bass Clef (F Clef)
concepts.description: A clef that places F below middle C on the fourth line of the staff
learning_objectives: Read notes in bass clef
Identify that the bass clef dots surround the F line
examples: Piano left hand typically uses bass clef
Cello music is written in bass clef

concepts.name: Ledger Lines
concepts.description: Short lines added above or below the staff to extend its range
learning_objectives: Read notes on ledger lines
Understand that ledger lines extend the staff's pitch range
examples: Middle C is on a ledger line below the treble clef staff
High notes may require multiple ledger lines above the staff

concepts.name: Accidental
concepts.description: A symbol that alters the pitch of a note (sharp, flat, natural)
learning_objectives: Identify sharp, flat, and natural symbols
Understand that accidentals modify the pitch of notes
examples: A sharp raises a note by a half step
A flat lowers a note by a half step
A natural cancels a previous accidental

concepts.name: Sharp (#)
concepts.description: An accidental that raises a note by one half step
learning_objectives: Identify the sharp symbol
Apply sharps to raise pitches by a half step
examples: C# is one half step higher than C
F# is the black key to the right of F on a piano

concepts.name: Flat (♭)
concepts.description: An accidental that lowers a note by one half step
learning_objectives: Identify the flat symbol
Apply flats to lower pitches by a half step
examples: B♭ is one half step lower than B
E♭ is the black key to the left of E on a piano

concepts.name: Natural (♮)
concepts.description: An accidental that cancels a previous sharp or flat, returning to the natural pitch
learning_objectives: Identify the natural symbol
Understand when and why naturals are used
examples: If a note was F#, an F♮ returns it to F natural
Naturals are used to cancel key signature accidentals

concepts.name: Half Step (Semitone)
concepts.description: The smallest interval in Western music, the distance between two adjacent keys on a piano
learning_objectives: Identify half steps on a keyboard and in notation
Understand half steps as the building blocks of intervals
examples: E to F is a half step (no black key between)
C to C# is a half step
B to C is a half step

concepts.name: Whole Step (Tone)
concepts.description: An interval equal to two half steps
learning_objectives: Identify whole steps on a keyboard and in notation
Understand that a whole step equals two half steps
examples: C to D is a whole step
F to G is a whole step
G to A is a whole step

concepts.name: Interval
concepts.description: The distance between two pitches, measured in steps and quality
learning_objectives: Understand intervals as the relationship between two pitches
Recognize that intervals are fundamental to harmony and melody
examples: C to E is an interval
G to D is an interval
Intervals can be played simultaneously (harmonic) or sequentially (melodic)

concepts.name: Interval Number
concepts.description: The numeric size of an interval, counting letter names inclusively (unison, 2nd, 3rd, 4th, 5th, 6th, 7th, octave)
learning_objectives: Count interval numbers by counting letter names
Identify intervals from unison to octave
examples: C to E is a 3rd (C=1, D=2, E=3)
F to C is a 5th (F=1, G=2, A=3, B=4, C=5)

concepts.name: Interval Quality
concepts.description: The specific character of an interval (major, minor, perfect, augmented, diminished)
learning_objectives: Distinguish between major and minor intervals
Identify perfect intervals
Understand augmented and diminished intervals
examples: C to E is a major 3rd (4 half steps)
C to E♭ is a minor 3rd (3 half steps)
C to G is a perfect 5th (7 half steps)

concepts.name: Perfect Interval
concepts.description: Intervals with a unique, stable quality: unison, 4th, 5th, and octave
learning_objectives: Identify perfect unisons, 4ths, 5ths, and octaves
Understand the acoustic stability of perfect intervals
examples: C to C is a perfect unison (0 half steps)
C to F is a perfect 4th (5 half steps)
C to G is a perfect 5th (7 half steps)
C to C' is a perfect octave (12 half steps)

concepts.name: Major Interval
concepts.description: The larger form of 2nds, 3rds, 6ths, and 7ths found in the major scale
learning_objectives: Identify major 2nds, 3rds, 6ths, and 7ths
Understand that major intervals are derived from the major scale
examples: C to D is a major 2nd (2 half steps)
C to E is a major 3rd (4 half steps)
C to A is a major 6th (9 half steps)
C to B is a major 7th (11 half steps)

concepts.name: Minor Interval
concepts.description: The smaller form of 2nds, 3rds, 6ths, and 7ths, one half step smaller than major
learning_objectives: Identify minor 2nds, 3rds, 6ths, and 7ths
Understand that minor intervals are one half step smaller than major
examples: C to D♭ is a minor 2nd (1 half step)
C to E♭ is a minor 3rd (3 half steps)
C to A♭ is a minor 6th (8 half steps)
C to B♭ is a minor 7th (10 half steps)

concepts.name: Rhythm
concepts.description: The pattern of durations and accents in music over time
learning_objectives: Understand rhythm as the organization of time in music
Recognize basic rhythmic patterns
examples: A steady quarter note pattern: ♩ ♩ ♩ ♩
A syncopated rhythm with varied durations

concepts.name: Beat
concepts.description: A regular pulse that underlies music, like a musical heartbeat
learning_objectives: Feel and identify the beat in music
Understand beat as the basic unit of musical time
examples: Tapping your foot to music follows the beat
A metronome click marks each beat

concepts.name: Tempo
concepts.description: The speed of the beat, typically measured in beats per minute (BPM)
learning_objectives: Understand tempo as the speed of music
Recognize common tempo markings (Allegro, Andante, etc.)
examples: Allegro = fast tempo (120-168 BPM)
Andante = walking tempo (76-108 BPM)
Adagio = slow tempo (66-76 BPM)

concepts.name: Meter
concepts.description: The organization of beats into regular patterns of strong and weak beats
learning_objectives: Recognize common meters (4/4, 3/4, 6/8)
Feel the difference between duple, triple, and other meters
examples: 4/4 time: STRONG-weak-medium-weak
3/4 time (waltz): STRONG-weak-weak

concepts.name: Time Signature
concepts.description: A notation showing the meter: top number = beats per measure, bottom number = note value for the beat
learning_objectives: Read and interpret time signatures
Understand the meaning of both numbers in a time signature
examples: 4/4 = four quarter notes per measure
3/4 = three quarter notes per measure
6/8 = six eighth notes per measure

concepts.name: Measure (Bar)
concepts.description: A segment of time defined by the time signature, separated by vertical bar lines
learning_objectives: Identify measures in written music
Understand that measures organize music into equal time units
examples: In 4/4 time, each measure contains four beats
Bar lines separate one measure from the next

concepts.name: Note Value (Note Duration)
concepts.description: The relative duration of a note (whole, half, quarter, eighth, etc.)
learning_objectives: Identify common note values and their symbols
Understand the relative durations of different note values
examples: Whole note (𝅝) = 4 beats in 4/4 time
Half note (𝅗𝅥) = 2 beats in 4/4 time
Quarter note (♩) = 1 beat in 4/4 time
Eighth note (♪) = 1/2 beat in 4/4 time

concepts.name: Rest
concepts.description: A symbol indicating silence for a specific duration
learning_objectives: Identify rest symbols and their durations
Understand that rests are as important as notes in rhythm
examples: Whole rest = 4 beats of silence in 4/4 time
Quarter rest = 1 beat of silence in 4/4 time

concepts.name: Dot (Dotted Note)
concepts.description: A dot placed after a note or rest that increases its duration by half
learning_objectives: Calculate the duration of dotted notes
Understand the dot adds half the original value
examples: Dotted half note = 3 beats (2 + 1)
Dotted quarter note = 1.5 beats (1 + 0.5)

concepts.name: Tie
concepts.description: A curved line connecting two notes of the same pitch, combining their durations
learning_objectives: Recognize tied notes in notation
Calculate the total duration of tied notes
examples: A quarter note tied to another quarter note = 2 beats total
Ties are used to sustain notes across bar lines

concepts.name: Scale
concepts.description: An ordered collection of pitches, typically spanning an octave, following a specific pattern of intervals
learning_objectives: Understand scales as organized collections of pitches
Recognize that scales are built using specific interval patterns
examples: The C major scale: C-D-E-F-G-A-B-C
Scales provide the tonal framework for melodies and harmonies

concepts.name: Major Scale
concepts.description: A seven-note scale with the interval pattern: W-W-H-W-W-W-H (W=whole step, H=half step)
learning_objectives: Build major scales from any starting note
Recognize the characteristic bright sound of major scales
examples: C major scale: C-D-E-F-G-A-B-C (no sharps or flats)
G major scale: G-A-B-C-D-E-F#-G (one sharp: F#)

concepts.name: Minor Scale
concepts.description: A seven-note scale with a darker, more somber character than major; exists in natural, harmonic, and melodic forms
learning_objectives: Build natural minor scales using W-H-W-W-H-W-W pattern
Recognize the darker sound of minor scales
examples: A natural minor: A-B-C-D-E-F-G-A
E natural minor: E-F#-G-A-B-C-D-E

concepts.name: Scale Degree
concepts.description: The position of a note within a scale, numbered 1-7 (or 1-8 including the octave)
learning_objectives: Identify scale degrees by number
Understand the functional names of scale degrees
examples: In C major: C=1 (tonic), D=2, E=3, F=4 (subdominant), G=5 (dominant), A=6, B=7 (leading tone)
Scale degrees show the relationship of notes to the tonal center

concepts.name: Tonic
concepts.description: The first scale degree and home note of a key; provides the strongest sense of stability and resolution
learning_objectives: Identify the tonic of a key
Understand the tonic as the point of greatest stability
examples: In the key of C major, C is the tonic
Melodies and pieces typically end on the tonic

concepts.name: Dominant
concepts.description: The fifth scale degree; creates tension that resolves to the tonic
learning_objectives: Identify the dominant in any key
Understand the dominant's role in creating tension and motion
examples: In C major, G is the dominant
Dominant chords typically resolve to tonic chords

concepts.name: Key
concepts.description: The tonal center of a piece, based on a specific scale (e.g., the key of C major or A minor)
learning_objectives: Identify the key of a piece from its key signature
Understand that key establishes the tonal framework
examples: A piece in the key of G major is based on the G major scale
The key signature shows which notes are sharp or flat throughout

concepts.name: Key Signature
concepts.description: Sharps or flats placed at the beginning of the staff to indicate the key
learning_objectives: Read key signatures to identify the key
Understand the order of sharps and flats in key signatures
examples: One sharp (F#) = G major or E minor
Two flats (B♭, E♭) = B♭ major or G minor
Order of sharps: F#-C#-G#-D#-A#-E#-B#
Order of flats: B♭-E♭-A♭-D♭-G♭-C♭-F♭

concepts.name: Chord
concepts.description: Three or more notes played simultaneously, creating harmony
learning_objectives: Understand chords as simultaneous pitch combinations
Recognize chords as the foundation of harmony
examples: C-E-G played together forms a C major chord
Chords can be played on piano, guitar, or by multiple instruments

concepts.name: Triad
concepts.description: A three-note chord built by stacking two thirds (root, third, fifth)
learning_objectives: Identify the root, third, and fifth of a triad
Build triads from any root note
examples: C major triad: C (root) - E (third) - G (fifth)
Triads are the most basic and common chords

concepts.name: Major Triad
concepts.description: A triad with a major third (4 half steps) and perfect fifth (7 half steps) above the root
learning_objectives: Build major triads from any root
Recognize the bright, happy sound of major triads
examples: C major: C-E-G (major 3rd + minor 3rd)
G major: G-B-D

concepts.name: Minor Triad
concepts.description: A triad with a minor third (3 half steps) and perfect fifth (7 half steps) above the root
learning_objectives: Build minor triads from any root
Recognize the darker, sadder sound of minor triads
examples: A minor: A-C-E (minor 3rd + major 3rd)
D minor: D-F-A

concepts.name: Diminished Triad
concepts.description: A triad with a minor third and diminished fifth (6 half steps) above the root
learning_objectives: Build diminished triads from any root
Recognize the tense, unstable sound of diminished triads
examples: B diminished: B-D-F (minor 3rd + minor 3rd)
Often used as leading-tone chords

concepts.name: Augmented Triad
concepts.description: A triad with a major third and augmented fifth (8 half steps) above the root
learning_objectives: Build augmented triads from any root
Recognize the bright, unsettled sound of augmented triads
examples: C augmented: C-E-G# (major 3rd + major 3rd)
Less common than major, minor, and diminished triads

concepts.name: Seventh Chord
concepts.description: A four-note chord built by adding a seventh above the root to a triad
learning_objectives: Identify seventh chords by their structure
Understand that seventh chords add color and tension to harmony
examples: C7 (dominant seventh): C-E-G-B♭
Cmaj7 (major seventh): C-E-G-B

concepts.name: Chord Inversion
concepts.description: A rearrangement of chord tones so that a note other than the root is in the bass
learning_objectives: Identify chord inversions
Understand that inversions create smoother voice leading
examples: C major root position: C-E-G (C in bass)
C major first inversion: E-G-C (E in bass)
C major second inversion: G-C-E (G in bass)

concepts.name: Harmony
concepts.description: The combination of simultaneous pitches; the vertical aspect of music
learning_objectives: Understand harmony as the vertical dimension of music
Recognize how harmony supports and enriches melody
examples: A piano accompaniment providing chords under a melody
Multiple voices singing different notes simultaneously

concepts.name: Melody
concepts.description: A sequence of pitches perceived as a single, coherent musical line; the horizontal aspect of music
learning_objectives: Recognize melody as a succession of pitches over time
Understand melody as the "tune" of a piece
examples: The tune you whistle or hum from a song
A vocal line in a pop song

concepts.name: Consonance
concepts.description: Intervals or chords that sound stable, pleasant, and restful
learning_objectives: Identify consonant intervals (unisons, 3rds, 5ths, 6ths, octaves)
Recognize the stable sound of consonance
examples: Perfect octaves and fifths are very consonant
Major and minor thirds are consonant
Major triads have a consonant sound

concepts.name: Dissonance
concepts.description: Intervals or chords that sound unstable, tense, and seek resolution
learning_objectives: Identify dissonant intervals (2nds, 7ths, tritone)
Understand that dissonance creates tension and motion in music
examples: Minor 2nds and major 7ths are highly dissonant
The tritone (augmented 4th/diminished 5th) is very dissonant
Dissonant chords typically resolve to consonant ones

concepts.name: Chord Progression
concepts.description: A succession of chords played in sequence
learning_objectives: Recognize common chord progressions
Understand that progressions create harmonic motion and structure
examples: I-IV-V-I (C-F-G-C in C major)
ii-V-I (common in jazz)
I-V-vi-IV (popular in contemporary music)

concepts.name: Cadence
concepts.description: A harmonic or melodic formula that creates a sense of resolution or rest at the end of a phrase
learning_objectives: Identify different types of cadences
Understand cadences as musical punctuation
examples: Authentic cadence: V-I (sounds conclusive)
Plagal cadence: IV-I ("Amen" cadence)
Half cadence: ends on V (sounds incomplete)

concepts.name: Phrase
concepts.description: A musical unit, typically 2-8 measures, that expresses a complete musical thought
learning_objectives: Identify phrases in music
Understand phrases as musical "sentences"
examples: "Twinkle, twinkle, little star" is a musical phrase
Phrases often end with cadences

concepts.name: Motif (Motive)
concepts.description: A short musical idea that recurs and develops throughout a piece
learning_objectives: Identify motifs in music
Recognize how motifs are varied and developed
examples: The four-note "fate" motif in Beethoven's Fifth Symphony
A short rhythmic or melodic pattern that repeats

concepts.name: Transposition
concepts.description: Moving a melody, chord, or entire piece to a different pitch level while maintaining the same intervals
learning_objectives: Transpose melodies to different keys
Understand that transposition preserves interval relationships
examples: Moving a melody from C major to G major
Raising a song by a whole step to suit a singer's range

concepts.name: Modulation
concepts.description: Changing from one key to another within a piece of music
learning_objectives: Recognize when music modulates to a new key
Understand common modulation techniques
examples: Moving from C major to G major in the middle of a piece
Many songs modulate up a half or whole step for the final chorus

concepts.name: Dynamics (Musical Dynamics)
concepts.description: Variations in loudness; indicated by symbols like p (piano/soft) and f (forte/loud)
learning_objectives: Interpret dynamic markings
Understand dynamics as a tool for musical expression
examples: pp (pianissimo) = very soft
ff (fortissimo) = very loud
mf (mezzo-forte) = moderately loud

concepts.name: Articulation
concepts.description: The way notes are played or sung, affecting their attack, sustain, and release
learning_objectives: Recognize articulation markings in notation
Perform notes with appropriate articulation
examples: Staccato (dots above notes) = short and detached
Legato (curved line) = smooth and connected
Accent (>) = emphasized

concepts.name: Musical Form
concepts.description: The overall structure or architecture of a piece of music
learning_objectives: Identify common musical forms
Understand how form organizes musical material
examples: Binary form: AB (two contrasting sections)
Ternary form: ABA (return to opening material)
Verse-chorus form in popular music

concepts.name: Musical Texture
concepts.description: The way melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials are combined in music
learning_objectives: Identify different musical textures
Understand how texture affects the character of music
examples: Monophonic: a single melody line (Gregorian chant)
Homophonic: melody with accompaniment (most pop songs)
Polyphonic: multiple independent melody lines (fugue)

concepts.name: Voice Leading
concepts.description: The way individual melodic lines (voices) move from one chord to another
learning_objectives: Understand principles of smooth voice leading
Write chord progressions with good voice leading
examples: Moving by step rather than leap when possible
Avoiding parallel fifths and octaves
Resolving tendency tones (like the leading tone to tonic)

concepts.name: Roman Numeral Analysis
concepts.description: A system for labeling chords based on their scale degree using Roman numerals (I, ii, iii, IV, V, vi, vii°)
learning_objectives: Label chords with Roman numerals
Understand that uppercase = major, lowercase = minor
Analyze chord progressions using Roman numerals
examples: In C major: C chord = I, Dm = ii, G = V
I-IV-V-I progression (tonic-subdominant-dominant-tonic)

concepts.name: Enharmonic Equivalents
concepts.description: Notes that sound the same but are written differently (e.g., C# and D♭)
learning_objectives: Identify enharmonic equivalents
Understand when to use each spelling
examples: C# = D♭ (same pitch, different notation)
F# = G♭
E# = F (enharmonic but unusual spelling)

concepts.name: Chromatic
concepts.description: Relating to all twelve pitches (including sharps and flats) rather than just the seven notes of a diatonic scale
learning_objectives: Understand the chromatic scale as all twelve pitches
Recognize chromatic notes as those outside the key
examples: The chromatic scale: C-C#-D-D#-E-F-F#-G-G#-A-A#-B-C
A chromatic passage uses notes outside the diatonic scale

concepts.name: Diatonic
concepts.description: Relating to the seven notes of a major or minor scale, without chromatic alterations
learning_objectives: Identify diatonic notes within a key
Distinguish diatonic from chromatic notes
examples: In C major, C-D-E-F-G-A-B are diatonic
C# would be chromatic in C major

metadata.author: Personal Learning Assistant 2026
metadata.description: A comprehensive atomic-granularity concept graph for music theory, designed to support personalized learning paths and adaptive education systems.
